text:
I squeezed my eyes shut. With a single leap, I landed at the highest
place in the land. The ocean was a shiny mongrel which drank at my
feet. Swivelling around my skull was a charcoal cloud, shaking out
jumbo jets and geese - they fell on my shoulders like dandruff.
And I heard your voice. Spinning through the air, I came to you. I had
barely moved from the rest of my life.

Travel is not cheap. I needed cash badly - I walked into a shop and
threatened the woman behind the till. Swore I'd slice her open and she
gave me everything, trembling tip to toe. (She'd forgive me, I'm
sure.) I hid for eight months writing the novel and then burnt it.
Because when I stared at them over and over, phrases giggled and
crumpled at the knees. They were meant to hold you up.
I work as a teacher, telling all sorts of lies to the children in my
class. They love me. They cling to my suit, claw at my polka dot tie.
I show them how to hate their parents - God, how they learn! The other
day the sunset was whining away. Bursting with pain, bursting with
blood, my stuck pig sky. I stood, an emperor, watching all this from
the school roof; sticking a joint into myself, burning off the end,
sucking that gas.
But the sun can be a snowball, a freezing disc unbothered by the blue
air around. I have to be careful on days like this, hide inside in
case thoughts of you - thugs - ambush me. Oh, the way your head would
jerk towards mine when I snaked my arms around your waist, and how
you'd turn into an upwards curve, snapping to attention. Every bump of
your lovely spine.

We once went to a forest where conifers, too tall for the tops to be
visible, shot up from a bed of overfed ferns, where invisible birds
flew between branches cooing, cackling, chomping on flying insects.
The day was stuffed full of heat and I was heavy. But you were so
light. You could run up trees, rise upwards on thousands of tiny
particles, leaving the canopy, and me, far behind.

Emerging opposite a field dotted with sheep, we sat on the matted
grass and had our lunch. We ate our stale sandwiches, and when those
were gone we ate the day itself. And you were soon to leave!

I'll haul out the wings and fly away. I'll fly past the motorised bed
and the nurse and past the other sick idiots; past the gleaming
machines, past reception, past the lobby, past the ring road of
relatives and their nodding sympathy. I'll fly into the funny orange
light of the city at night, which used to curl around my curtains when
I was a small boy. And sometimes it would even crawl under the covers
and hold me - stay by my side murmuring the lullaby of distant cars,
making dark shimmer on the walls.

I squeezed my eyes shut. With a single leap, I landed at the highest
place in the land. The ocean was a shiny mongrel which drank at my
feet. Swivelling around my skull was a charcoal cloud, shaking out
jumbo jets and geese =E2=80=94 they fell on my shoulders like dandruff.
And I heard your voice. Spinning through the air, I came to you. I had
barely moved from the rest of my life.

Travel is not cheap. I needed cash badly =E2=80=94 I walked into a shop and
threatened the woman behind the till. Swore I=E2=80=99d slice her open and =
she
gave me everything, trembling tip to toe. (She=E2=80=99d forgive me, I=E2=
=80=99m
sure.) I hid for eight months writing the novel and then burnt it.
Because when I stared at them over and over, phrases giggled and
crumpled at the knees. They were meant to hold you up.
I work as a teacher, telling all sorts of lies to the children in my
class. They love me. They cling to my suit, claw at my polka dot tie.
I show them how to hate their parents =E2=80=94 God, how they learn! The ot=
her
day the sunset was whining away. Bursting with pain, bursting with
blood, my stuck pig sky. I stood, an emperor, watching all this from
the school roof; sticking a joint into myself, burning off the end,
sucking that gas.
But the sun can be a snowball, a freezing disc unbothered by the blue
air around. I have to be careful on days like this, hide inside in
case thoughts of you =E2=80=94 thugs =E2=80=94 ambush me. Oh, the way your =
head would
jerk towards mine when I snaked my arms around your waist, and how
you=E2=80=99d turn into an upwards curve, snapping to attention. Every bump=
 of
your lovely spine.

We once went to a forest where conifers, too tall for the tops to be
visible, shot up from a bed of overfed ferns, where invisible birds
flew between branches cooing, cackling, chomping on flying insects.
The day was stuffed full of heat and I was heavy. But you were so
light. You could run up trees, rise upwards on thousands of tiny
particles, leaving the canopy, and me, far behind.

Emerging opposite a field dotted with sheep, we sat on the matted
grass and had our lunch. We ate our stale sandwiches, and when those
were gone we ate the day itself. And you were soon to leave!

I=E2=80=99ll haul out the wings and fly away. I=E2=80=99ll fly past the mot=
orised bed
and the nurse and past the other sick idiots; past the gleaming
machines, past reception, past the lobby, past the ring road of
relatives and their nodding sympathy. I=E2=80=99ll fly into the funny orang=
e
light of the city at night, which used to curl around my curtains when
I was a small boy. And sometimes it would even crawl under the covers
and hold me =E2=80=94 stay by my side murmuring the lullaby of distant cars=
,
making dark shimmer on the walls.
